plist.p: Good morning. Welcome. Thank you for coming to our Preliminary Results Presentation today.

The agenda today is slightly different than usual. I will give the usual highlights to open. Then I will pass to Andy, who will cover all the financial information and the guidance. Then I will come back with Steve Pusey to illustrate the progress we made in the implementation of our strategy and in particular the growth areas, technology as an enabler of our SuperMobile strategy and challenges and opportunities in the year ahead, and then we will open to questions.

So highlights. Group organic service revenue plus 2.1% in the year, in the quarter four plus 2.5%. I would say we have displaying today – we are displaying today a strong commercial performance in most European and most emerging markets, exceeded guidance AOP at £12.2 billion at the top end of the range and free cash flow at £7.2 billion, again at the top end of the range.

We have raised or we are in the process of raising £14.2 billion from disposals with £6.8 billion of those committed to share buybacks. And finally, we are recommending today an increase in our dividend per share of 7.1% to 6.05p leading to the total to 8.90p which again is 7.1%. And as we highlight to you later, I think we have made good progress on our strategic priorities.
Let me now turn to Andy who will cover results and guidance.

Right, good morning and hopefully my voice will hold up, so just some key numbers on here. So £45.9 billion total revenue for the period, 3% up year-on-year, EBITDA £14.7 billion, and I will come to more detail on this in a bit, but that's basically sort of flat to slightly down on the last year. And £11.8 billion published adjusted operating profit. The numbers that Vittorio had there were on the same FX rates as we guided at.

And then two important numbers there on the lower slide here, a gain of £5.3 billion and impairment charges of £6.1 billion. So the gain of £5.3 billion is the aggregate benefit we've had from the profit on disposal of the China Mobile interest, SoftBank and some tax provision releases. And on the impairment side, we took a charge if you remember at the half-year for Greece. We have now topped that up primarily for Spain, but also for Ireland, Portugal and Italy. And the total for the year is £6.1 billion. That is driven in part by macroeconomic, particularly Southern Europe, but in larger part by interest rate rises and the impact that that has on discount rates. The adjusted earnings per share then was up 4% at 16.75p.

So if I move then on to the service revenue, service revenue at £42.7 billion, was up by 2.1% on an organic basis for the year. I will talk about the quarterly trends on the next slide but £2.1 up for the full-year. Splitting that between the two regions, Europe was down very slightly minus 0.4% and AMAP was up by a very strong 9.5% and again I will give a bit more detail on those in a minute.

The EBITDA margin was down 1.1 percentage points, so we had originally said that we would see a reduced level of margin erosion compared with the previous year. That is what has happened, again, more detail later but a lot of that driven by cost savings offsetting the extra investment in SuperMobile and like customers.

Associated income £5.1 billion, the biggest part of that is Verizon wireless £4.6 billion and that is an 8.5% increase in contribution from the U.S. And free cash flow at just over £7 billion is the second year running that we have had the free cash flow over the £7 billion number some significant working capital in there but equally a continued focus on building out the network, which Steve will talk about later on.

So if you look at this in terms of quarterly trends in gray you have got the quarterly trends going back five quarters on the service revenue so we were negative five quarters ago, if you go back eight quarters we were sort of minus 3% territory and we have come through to 2.5% for the second successive quarter as we have exited the year.

And if anything that is, sort of, more commendable because as the red bar show to the numbers on an equivalent basis before the MTR cuts actually the impact of the MTR cuts was slightly more significant in the fourth quarter than it was in the third quarter.

In terms of the year-on-year walk we have added £1 billion of revenues over the period £41.7 billion in the previous year, £42.7 billion last year. I think the most noticeable thing here is how for the first time the data revenue increase has now fully funded the reduction in the voice revenues. The voice revenues itself being very, very largely shifted by the MTR cuts, but data now £5.1 billion for the full year, which is a 26% increase year-on-year and in fact the annualized rate in the last quarter was more about £5.5 billion.

So very strong performance on data and actually as you walk across this table in all other product areas: so messaging, fixed and wholesale, we have seen increases like-for-like on the revenue streams to come to the £42.7 billion number for the full year.

Now if I talk for a few minutes about operational performance, the European region as I've said earlier the revenues there are down 0.4% which is the gray bar on the right. What we have done here is shown the build of the various contributions from the different operating companies to get to that minus 0.4 number. The minus 0.4 itself was obviously MTR affected that would have been plus 2% but for the MTRs.

So you can see a very, very significant contribution from Turkey, I'll talk to each of this just briefly in a minute, U.K., Netherlands Germany and held back by Italy, Greece and Spain and there are details on each of the operating companies in the appendices to the pack.

So just very briefly then on Turkey, I mean, a really, really strong year 30% of revenue growth in the last quarter, similar actually to the full year run rate on revenue growth. They have taken 5.9 percentage points of service revenue market share in a 12% month period, ARPU up by 23% and overall business just performing really well. The mix of contract customers has also increased significantly about 16% a year ago now 28% and like our other businesses pushing very hard on the data front.

U.K., again, a good really good period for the U.K. Nice to see it now taking the largest revenue growth in the market, 5.8% in the fourth quarter revenue growth there, big, big focus upon data with the revenue stream there growing by very nearly 30%. Churn now coming down to sort of low levels and adding about 1 million net contract customers per annum and has been doing that as a regular basis recently.

Now, I'll not talk about Netherlands now, Vittorio has a couple of comments on that later on. So I will instead just move on to Germany. The numbers there most impacted by the impacts of the mobile termination rate cuts at the start of the quarter. So, if we had not had those the reported revenue growth of 0.2 would actually been a 4.4 percentage increase in the revenues.

Again, big push on data, very strong growth there, 25.5% on the data revenues and also very, very big push on enterprise with about 3.2% increase in the revenues from our enterprise customers, and again, a business that has gained market share in the second half of the year.

Moving then on to Italy, I think the best description here is a very, very strong performance against the main competitor, but a market that is now clearly more difficult. We had overall service revenue decline of 3% which was broadly the mobile going backwards by 5%, but the fixed going forwards, going upwards by double-digits. Data, again, a big push, 20% growth in data revenues and exited the period with 5.5 million smartphone customers.

In Spain, we have reported 5.9% revenue decline for the fourth quarter. There were couple of accounting true-ups, so on an underlying basis it is more 7.7%, so pretty similar to the trends that we have seen in recent quarters, still quite a challenging environment, still pushing very hard on data and a number of pricing and distribution and advertising initiatives that have been pushed in the market even in recent weeks.

So in terms of the areas that the European region was focused upon at the start of the year, top left here is the push to smartphones, so 18.7% of the base have now got smartphones, that is up about seven percentage points compared with the year previously. Top right, a big focus upon the enterprise base, that is now approaching £9 billion of revenues and a lot of big customer wins there. In fact our Vodafone Global Enterprise business unit grew its revenues by 8% during the year.

Repositioning key markets, bottom left, particularly the U.K. and Turkey clearly are gaining traction. And finally and I think particularly importantly, the focus that there has been on cost has resulted in the second successive year of the cost in Europe coming down by around 4%.

So moving then on the AMAP region, I said earlier, 9.5% growth for the region overall. India has clearly been the biggest contributor there, but essentially all but one country have been in positive territory, the one country being Egypt. If we have cut this off at the end of December Egypt would have been in positive territory as well. So, clearly, down rest in the last quarter has just nudged that slightly the wrong side of the line for the moment. But nonetheless across the whole of the region I think a very, very strong performance.

So if you just look again at the key markets here, India had service revenue growth in last quarter of 18.7%. We had record net customer adds in the last quarter at 10.3 million. We gained 1.8 percentage points of revenue market share during the period and continue to see market prices stabilizing. So I think the operational performance in India has been really, really strong.

For the Vodacom Group and for South Africa as well, again, growth there has been good. We have seen in the South African market growth of about 6% and that has been both the push on voice where the minutes-of-use per customer is now rising quite nicely and also a big push on data; 37% growth in data and particularly mobile broadband that is helping (14:05) to drive that.

So in terms of the AMAP region and its strategic priorities, the total customer base at the end of the period for the region is now 220 million customers. That is a 26% increase year-on-year. India is about 61% of that total base.

On the top right I think a very important chart, the free cash flow, the operating free cash flow being generated by this region has gone up from essentially nothing up to over £1.5 billion and now near £2.5 billion over a three-year period; so a very, very significant increase there contributing nearly a quarter of the Group's operating free cash flow.

Data on the bottom left also a good story. 40% increase in data revenues, so a total of £1.2 billion, and so of the Group's £5.1 billion, £1.2 billion is coming from these markets. And then finally a lot of this being achieved by the push we had have on new devices and new innovative products to get really the brand name further extended into the market.

So, I'll move now off the sort of operating performance of the countries and just talk a little bit about the financials. The EBITDA to margin, which I know a lot of people have an interest in, top left hand chart is showing the 1.1% reduction in the margin year-on-year at the group level. And it is showing that the vast majority of that reduction was Europe. AMAP was, in the overall scheme of things, fairly constant.

The bottom left hand chart then is focused on Europe, which is showing really two key drivers there, one is the big focus on smartphones, acquiring new customers; the other is the initiatives we've had to get costs out of the business and to in part fund the customer growth. As I said earlier the growth in the customers has really started to pull through some percentage points more smartphone penetration in the base than we had a year ago.

We now have 39% of our European customer base on contract compared to 37% year ago. The business churn is now down a percentage point compared with the year ago. So huge focus there and really I think starting to pull through a lot of costs initiatives, which have helped to fund some of that.

AMAP I think important to note AMAP is now 27% of the group's EBITDA up from 22% a year ago. The margins there were up about 20 basis points year-on-year and certainly as we go forwards and look to the scale benefits we are very comfortable that we should see a good margin performance in the AMAP region over the coming quarters.

Now on to the U.S., Verizon Wireless, as I said earlier another strong period here so just on the $60 billion of revenues, up by 5.8% took most of the total market contract net adds in the last quarter, churn down at very, very low levels and free cash flow generation very, very strong. A year ago about $22 billion of net debt, at end of March that was down to $9.6 billion, so basically down $1 billion a month or I think in the duration of this presentation about $2 million less debt by the end of it than the start of it.

In terms of margin, the overall comparison of margins in the – across the operators in the U.S. again Verizon Wireless compares very favorably there. Data has been a big part of that push, coincidently also a 26% increase in the data revenues. So similar to what we've got in Vodafone and smartphone penetration also being pushed, interestingly somewhat higher levels than we've so far achieved in Europe.

And there has been a lot of focus on the LTE rollout. So as I am sure many of you all know that has now commenced, there will be by the end of this calendar year about 185 million of the population will be able to get LTE service. And there are today 500,000 4G devices in active use.

And we are working ever more closely with Verizon on a number of initiatives, particularly on major customer accounts, where we've got common interest in those accounts. Also on the procurement side, we clearly spend huge amounts between the two businesses and also looking at the LTE roadmap which with our embarking upon that in Germany and other markets in due course, is clearly an area where there are joint learnings for both of us.

So on to finance costs, the bottom line £815 million is fairly similar to last year, but I think the key things is to observe that there are some non-recurring items that are included in these numbers. So the top part of this chart, you can see £1.2 billion of financing cost.

Underneath that there are three items which will not recur, one is we have been accreting the value of the SoftBank Financial instruments prior to the disposal in the financing cost line. Secondly, the benefit of the China Mobile dividends comes through here; and thirdly, we were capitalizing the cost of some of the borrowings to do the India 3G license, which obviously will not be a recurring feature, that only happens up until the launch of the 3G service.

So basically we should be thinking that the £1.2 billion number is sort of the underlying watermark there. That was about a 4% finance cost. I would expect that we will see the finance cost for the coming year start with the number 5. We have got rising interest rates. We are fixing more. We will actually have more cash on deposit for a period this year when we have the SFR proceeds in, etcetera.

So on free cash flow; we were £7.2 billion at the prior year. We've closed last year at £7.0 billion. Important to note in here is that there is a significant working capital contribution. We have pushed very hard on working capital again. So the £0.5 billion you can see here is the increase year-on-year. In reality we had about £0.5 billion in the previous year. We have got about £1 billion, so £1 billion of the £7 billion is actually working capital in the current year.

Cap adds, interest, EBITDA all fairly similar; slightly higher cash and tax outflows just because of some tax benefits in the previous year; slightly higher minority dividend payments particularly in South Africa and Egypt; and the FX having a £0.2 billion effect so overall the £7 billion.

Just put on the right here the – just as a sort of guide going forward, we will not be generating £1 billion a year of working capital, much as I'd like to be doing that. I don't think that is realistic; is not going to happen. So we sort of put that down implicitly to about £0.3 billion next year. That will still be about £2 billion of working capital though generated over a three-year period. And clearly next year we will not have the benefits of some of the cash streams coming in. So we will get the reduced SFR dividend as a consequence of the exit agreement and we will not have a China Mobile dividend. So on a, sort of, pro forma basis sort of £6 billion is a core number, which I'll come back to when we come on to the guidance.

Net debt at the start of the period was £33 billion and net debt at the end of the period was just fractionally under £30 billion. Some quite big moving parts in that, so the free cash flow, the £7 billion we just talked about, £4.5 billion of equity dividends paid out. The share buyback at the end of March was £2.1 billion. Acquisitions and disposal, that is primarily the proceeds from the China Mobile disposal and the first tranche of the Softbank proceeds.

Licenses and spectrum was the Indian and Germany spectrum auctions in the first half of the year. Tax related payments was primarily the first payment of the CFC resolution in the UK plus some tax on the disposal in China Mobile and then there were some FX movements and the total £30 billion or £29.9 billion at the end of the period. So I think that leaves us in good shape for the coming period as we go forwards.

So turning on to sort of portfolio. I think if you step back, this has been a pretty significant year and we said a year ago that we had a number of non-controlled assets that we wanted to work our way through. We appreciate the patience that shareholders have shown so we are able to time these and get what we believe have been very good prices out of those assets.

So, at a high level £14.2 billion raised, that's net of very small tax charge, but not significant. About half of that is committed to share buybacks so £6.8 billion and the rest we have retained in the knowledge we got spectrum auctions and tax cases around. So overall I think this is a right balance between returns and the management of the balance sheet.

You can see on the left-hand side in terms of return to shareholders, the combination over the last three years of the dividends plus the buybacks, is about £16 billion that had been returned in cash by the end of March.

We have still got the buyback commitment of the £4 billion from the SFR disposal and the remainder of the first buyback programs still to complete, that is another £5 billion. So, in total about £21 billion of cash going back, that is about 25% of our market cap. In addition, we have committed to continuing with the 7% per annum dividend increase. So, I think, we're in good shape in balance sheet and returns perspectives.

Now on to guidance. First of all, last year and how did that out turn? At this time last year we were saying we would be in the £11.2 billion to £12.0 billion range on the profit. We, in November, increased that to £11.8 billion to £12.2 billion and we have actually come out at £12.2 billion, and actually we have absorbed the iPhone launch costs of Verizon Wireless in getting to the £12.2 billion number. So in some senses that slightly understates the number.

Free cash flow, we said we would be above £6.5 billion. We've come in at a reported £7 billion or on the same FX basis at £7.2 billion. We said the margin reduction – rate reduction would be significantly lower. We've half the rate reduction. And on the CapEx, we said the CapEx would be at similar levels to the previous year, which is what has happened.

More importantly, moving on to the guidance for the year that has just started, first of all, just sort of some mathematical changes, clearly we're not going to have the profit contribution that will be coming in from the SFR disposal. We'll have a reduced cash flow coming in, as I mentioned earlier, because of the SFR disposal, China Mobile and the working capital. So, the sort of rebased numbers, if you like, are about £11.3 billion on the profit and £6 billion on free cash flow.

What we've done is looking at the overall environment we're in, the strength of the performance in many markets, the continuing challenges in the Southern European markets, MTR cuts etcetera, is we have put the guidance for the current year at £11.0 billion to £11.8 billion and the free cash flow at £6.0 billion to £6.5 billion.

So implicitly within that we're saying sort of 1 to 4% revenue, service revenue growth range we've given for the medium-term. Realistically, whilst we are still coming out of recession, we still got the MTR cuts. I think we will see ourself in the lower part of that. And I think we'll see ourself in the lower part of that in the first quarter of next year, and then hopefully over time as we come through that we can pick up the pace there.

In terms of the medium-term guidance, just one point on this, again, referring back to the loss of the cash streams from the two disposed asset, about £0.5 billion comes out of the cash flow as a consequence of that. So roughly £6 billion to £7 billion becomes instead £5.5 billion to £6.5 billion. Clearly, with having done the share buybacks, we've also reduced the number of shares in count and therefore the dividend basically is reducing proportionately and we're reconfirming the 1 to 4% target on the revenue growth and the target of having margins stable by the end of the period. And the dividend commitment for 7% per annum growth continues.

So in summary, before I hand back to Vittorio, I think a reasonably successful year, 2.1% of underlying growth, good control of costs, good control of CapEx and significant proceeds raised from disposals, with big commitments back to shareholders and the 7% increase in the dividend, underpinning all of that and maybe we will see where we go with the U.S. over time.
So with that, I'll hand back to Vittorio.

Thanks, Andy. What I would like to do now is to update you on the key elements of the growth strategy that we illustrated in November, last year highlighting, where we think we are doing well and also indicating where we think that either we or the industry should do better.

I will not cover all the growth elements that we indicated last year. I am not covering today total communications. We have a good growth in fixed, 5%. We'll not cover new services like machine-to-machine, where we have been doing well with £140 million, £150 million of revenues, but I will really focus on the three important ones, which are data, enterprise and emerging markets.

So let me start with data. Data clearly continues to be a good story for Vodafone, as you can see from the chart, we've moved our growth rate from 19% to 26%. Data is now 12% of revenue, mobile internet specifically is growing 54% and I have to say the story is still in the early days. Penetration bottom part of the chart, penetration of data users in Europe is 37%, up seven percentage points. But smartphone penetration, which is the blue bar is just at 19%.

So there is lots more ground to cover. And I have to say, we are talking mostly so far about contracts, they are still pre-paid, pre-paid is about 10% penetration in Europe and of course in emerging markets. So data is and continues to be the focus. At Vodafone, we have taken deliberately a leadership position here. As you can see the share of shipments of the smartphones it's the grey part of the top chart, has gone up, has gone up by choice, 38% now. It's clearly – there is an iPhone effect, but this is not just an iPhone effect.

Last year some of you might remember, I said we want sub €100 smartphones. We have got them. Actually today we are showing a new one, which is the Smart – the Vodafone Smart at €90. And we are convinced that the more we broaden our smartphone portfolio, the more we lower the enterprise; the better will be the economics of our data strategy.

Now an important element, very important element of the data strategy is what is in the box which is integrated data pricing and tiering. Now, it's very important. For some – we wanted to show you some case study or some practical examples, and for some reasons that I'm not sure I remember, we decided to pick the Netherlands, which are an interesting market.

Now Netherlands, the top part of the chart indicates that our trends, this is the full year trend. I think on your papers it might be printed Q4, but it's really full year, the full year trend of our revenues in the Netherlands. And, of course, as you can see, yes there is voice erosion especially driven by MTR. In the last quarter, there is also some kind of underlying voice erosion. But the other elements of our revenues: data, messaging and everything else are actually up and as a result revenues are up.

In the Netherlands we have a very good 77% attach rate. Attach rate is the amount of people who get a data pricing bundle together with a smartphone. And this has not happened, I would say, by its own. As you see in the bottom part of the chart, the proportion of our contract customers in the Netherlands who have an integrated voice data SMS plan, is now about half and it has come up a lot recently. This is very important, because when you ride the data wave, you also have to take into account customers' behavior, and customers' behavior is what drives at the end of the day what our revenues will be in the future.

So if you look at what has happened in The Netherlands, next slide, you see that our billed ARPU, so the part of the ARPU that the customers pay actually has remained broadly stable. This is clearly allocation of different components. So allowances for voice, for data, for SMS might have changed, but again part of our job is exactly to manage this mix, so to mix the ingredients, so that the recipe remains a tasty recipe for us.

The bottom part of the chart indicates what percentage of the total bill is actually contracted at the month, and this is again the second reason why it's very important to manage proactively pricing, because this reduces the risk that we have on our revenues for out of bundle usage. So customers within the bundle can move their usage on the communication platform that they prefer, but still we have a kind of higher proportion of our billed ARPU guaranteed.

Then the third element, which is very important, is what we'd call the tier pricing. You can see it -- again, this is the Dutch example, of course, in the bars. Customers get in at €25. For €25 they get 250 megabytes. But we are not giving away the upside potential. So, if they want to use more, they can give us €5 more. If they want to use much more and they also want to use VoIP, they can – for €40 kind of do what they want.

So not only we are kind of mitigating the impact of changes in behaviors from the customers but we are also preserving the possibility of the upside. This is clearly something that has to be managed it's not something that comes automatically but we think is the right answer to the trends in the data world.

Second element of the growth strategy that I illustrated in November was enterprise. Now enterprise is a very, very good area for Vodafone, it's today about 30% of our revenues in Europe, it's about 15% of our customers. In enterprise we had a 37% market share, which is good and it's a growth engine for Europe. In Europe we grew 0.5% in business in the total business area while consumer was down in the year.

And this is happening both at the mid-end and low-end where we have products like One Net where we basically leverage on the trend to get integrated fixed and mobile services for those type of companies. But also at the high-end Andy mentioned, VGE [Vodafone Global Enterprise] multinational accounts 8% growth interesting information, which is first time we disclose, our new contract value, which is a little bit what has been contracted for the future has for the first time this year exceeded £1 billion. It's very good not just for the blue blood names of customers that we get but also because, of course, this leverages on our strength.

Now in enterprise we see some trends which are I think comforting for Vodafone because we are in the right position to exploit them. Let me mention three, first mobile proliferation of mobile devices in companies is basically exploding. I often meet CEOs or CIOs to ask what's – what can we do for them, and the answer is always, please help us manage all these nice things that we all, I think more or less legally bring on the company's networks because we like to bring our own devices and we have iPods and tablets and PCs and MACs and everybody has his own taste. Companies are unable at this point to control this. But they need to control the impact of this which is the first request.

The second request is clearly helping them manage the complexity that is deriving from this: fixed mobile services together, spending which goes across different devices. And again, this is a strong request for telecommunication services management coming mostly from the high-end, but more and more also from mid-end and then, of course, the multi-county management thing kind of, can I have the same service from Vodafone across the 5, 6 and 10, 20, 50 markets where we work.

Now we at Vodafone have taken some actions, I think, early on, started probably two, three years ago. Let me mention a few of them. We have increased our sales force size, so it's the area of the company where we are hiring people. We have bought some companies with relevant assets, telecom expense management companies to help these companies manage – I'll say vertical and horizontal complexity. We had added new services. Of course, telecommunication services like One Net, but also more general services: security, device management, authentication and other things that are necessary in the company space to keep this booming area under control.

And finally, I want to mention cooperation with Verizon, not just Verizon Wireless, but Verizon more in general, which gives us ability to follow our customers more broadly and in more countries. So enterprise remains a strong area of focus for us.

And thirdly, emerging markets. Now I'm happy here to talk about the kind of four recently acquired or more recently acquired operations. We have 12% growth across them. We grow, Andy already mentioned, the great number in Turkey, about 30%, growth, might not be very big, but also 21% in Ghana is remarkable. India keeps growing well and at this point also being cash flow positive is a good contributor to the Group. South Africa, despite of the very high – the very high market share they continue to grow – to grow well.

At the core of this, two things: one, the brand. We have – the power of our brand is recognized everywhere. I received last night an e-mail, again from Ghana, I guess, where we got awarded, I don't know what special award for brand and brand management. We are now red even in Africa -- in the whole of Africa and we have speech marked, not rebranded, but speech marked Vodacom with great success. So, brand clearly is part of our strategy and it's clearly paying-off and the other one is clearly network, and Steve will cover more. But we are seeing that our ability to bring good technology and low cost technology everywhere is becoming more and more important.

And the result is in the market shares that you see at the bottom part of the chart. Andy has already mentioned some of the great results. But I would say, again, this is a proof that the recently acquired operations are well managed and Vodafone is able to manage both in mature and in emerging markets.

Looking forward, 70% penetration in the emerging markets, Europe is at much higher levels. So there is a voice opportunity going ahead. But I would say, and I always repeat, the most important thing is the data opportunity. In places where there is no Internet, where there is little communication – fixed communication, a penetration of 18% in India, indicates that there is a huge potential to go. We have doubled the number of active customers in India, but still we're talking about a very low number. And these are early days for 3G in most of these places, so emerging markets will continue to be a great area of focus.
Let me now handover for five minute to Steve who will talk about technology and how technology both IT and network side are enabling our SuperMobile strategy.

Thanks, Vittorio, and good morning. What I'd like to do this morning is share with you how our technical strategy is supporting our mobile data growth opportunity and to do that I will focus on four areas.

Firstly our network performance, then how our coverage strategy is evolving, how we are managing the data growth and the capacity, and lastly how we are changing our investment mix towards what we call unmatched customer experience.

Firstly network, we know from our customers that this really matters. It is the foundation of the customer experience and it's what our customers measure us by. To that end, we do annual tests. We use an independent company to do this, a German company in this case, called P3 and we just completed around the 13 primary European countries here which I will give you the reference to.

We are very pleased that we came out in front of our competition in 11 of the 13 markets and particularly strong in the largest four European countries. To support this, we are also very pleased that we further stretched our lead against competition in the key two attributes that customers measure and see as they're experiencing downloading video or streaming a piece of music which is downlink and uplink.
You can see from the charts that we've further stretched the experience difference against our competition. This really matters, and we will continue to focus on best network.

In addition to that, our customer base is moving and our footprint of customers is changing. With the advent of the smartphone the opportunity is a lot more ubiquitous. We know that people want to use their smartphones everywhere, and it has a huge data component and data opportunity.

So to match this, we have to evolve our coverage strategy, and simply put we aim to have data everywhere that we have voice. This metric would take us beyond the 90% coverage and to that end we just completed the build of 8,500 new sites in Europe. And we also introduced UMTS900 this is a re-farm spectrum, which has particularly beneficial coverage attributes.

So this is a policy we will continue throughout next year and the year beyond. But at the same time we've introduced a floor, a floor expectation of service for the customer.
